page.title: 10Landscape & Buildings
page.content: The houses and barns built of local stone blend into the landscape. At Stowe they nestle into the hillside while the others all have their shelter belt of trees. A stream runs through the old barn at Stowe, but the newer barns and cattle sheds are of concrete blocks, with corrugated iron roofs. The Stud Farm has a steel silo with fibreglass roof for corn storage. The church at Stowe is basically 13th century but little remains visible after 19th century 'restoration' when new windows were inserted into the thick stone walls, and the timber and stone porch and pyramidal wooden clapboard bell turret were added. The interior has a fine 17th century black and white timber roof and an unusual Italian 'Art Nouveau' reredos in mosaic panels of coloured stone, mother of pearl and copper.
